Bodhisattvas who have attained equal forbearance do not become angry or upset with any sentient being, like a loving mother caring for her child.
As a verse says:
Contemplate sound as an echo, bodily actions as reflections in a mirror;
If one can contemplate in this way, how can one not be patient?
This is called forbearance with regard to sentient beings.
What is called forbearance with regard to the Dharma?

Good dharmas, bad dharmas, with outflows, without outflows, conditioned, unconditioned, and so forth - such dharmas enter the gate of non-duality, enter the gate of the true characteristics of dharmas. Having entered in this way,
in the midst of deeply entering the true characteristics of dharmas, the mind forbears and directly enters without dispute or obstruction. This is called forbearance with regard to the Dharma.
As a verse says:
Dharmas are neither born nor extinguished, neither unborn nor un-extinguished,
Also not arising or ceasing, not not arising or ceasing,ğŸ”½also not not arising or ceasing,

Having already attained liberation (annotation: having attained freedom from wrong views, therefore it is said liberation); emptiness, non-emptiness (annotation: not grasping at emptiness, therefore it is said non; all of these are abandoned, extinguishing all frivolous arguments, the path of language is cut off, deeply entering the Buddha Dharma, the mind penetrates without obstruction, immovable and unretreating, called the forbearance of non-arising, this is the initial gateway to assisting the Buddha Way.

[Sutra] All of them have the five supernatural powers.
[Treatise] The supernatural powers of mind-reading, heavenly eye, heavenly ear, knowing others' minds, and remembering past lives.
What is the supernatural power of mind-reading?
There are three kinds of supernatural powers of mind-reading:
the ability to reach, transformation, and the noble supernatural powers.
The ability to reach has four kinds:
First, the body can fly like a bird without obstruction;
Second, moving far to near, not going but arriving;
Third, disappearing here and appearing there;
Fourth, being able to reach in a single thought.
As for transformation, the great can be made small, the small can be made great, one can be made many, and many can be made one. Various things can all be transformed.
The transformations of non-Buddhists cannot last more than seven days;
The transformations of Buddhas and their disciples are free and unrestricted, with no limit of duration.
As for the holy supernormal powers, among the six external sense objects, unlovely and impure things can be observed and made pure;
Lovely and pure things can be observed and made unlovely and impure.
This is the Dharma of the holy supernormal powers, which only the Buddha possesses alone.
This supernormal power of the mind arises from cultivating the four bases of supernormal power;
These bases of supernormal power and other supernormal powers arise in sequence because they have form as their object, and cannot be attained simultaneously.
As for the supernormal power of the heavenly eye, one obtains the pure form created by the four elements of the form realm in the eyes, which is called the heavenly eye.
The heavenly eye sees the various objects of sentient beings in the six destinies of one's own realm and lower realms, whether near or far, covered or subtle, without fail.
There are two kinds of heavenly eyes:
The first is obtained from retribution, and the second is obtained from cultivation.
Among the five supernatural powers, the heavenly eye is obtained from cultivation, not from retribution.
Why is it so?
Because one constantly recollects various lights and obtains them.
Furthermore, some say:

These bodhisattvas, by the power of attaining the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, are not included in the six destinies. They only manifest the Dharma body in the ten directions and three realms in order to teach and transform sentient beings;
Bodhisattvas who have not yet attained the Dharma body may either cultivate and obtain it or obtain it from retribution.
Question:

The merits of these bodhisattvas surpass those of arhats and pratyekabuddhas. Why then do you praise the minor merits shared by ordinary beings and the heavenly eye, but not the wisdom eye, Dharma eye, and buddha eye of the bodhisattvas?
Answer:
There are three kinds of heavenly beings:
1. Heavenly beings by designation, 2. Heavenly beings by birth, 3. Heavenly beings of purity.
Wheel-turning sage kings, other great kings, and so forth are called heavenly beings by designation;
From the Heaven of the Four Heavenly Kings up to the summit of existence, those born there are called heavenly beings by birth;
Buddhas, bodhisattvas with the Dharma body, pratyekabuddhas, and arhats are called heavenly beings of purity.
The heavenly eye cultivated by these heavenly beings of purity is called the supernormal power of the heavenly eye.

The pure heavenly eye of the Buddha, bodhisattvas with the Dharma body, is not attainable by ordinary beings with the five supernormal powers who are free from desires, nor is it attainable by Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Why is this so?
A small arhat with little effort sees a thousand worlds;
with great effort, he sees two thousand worlds.
A great arhat with little effort sees two thousand worlds;
with great effort, he sees a great trichiliocosm.
Pratyekabuddhas are also like this.
This is called the supernormal knowledge of the divine eye.
What is called the supernormal knowledge of the divine ear?
In the ear, one obtains the pure form created by the four great elements of the form realm, and can hear all sounds:
the sounds of gods, humans, and the three evil paths.
How does one attain the supernormal knowledge of the divine ear through cultivation?
Always recollecting various sounds.
This is called the supernormal knowledge of the divine ear.
What is called the supernormal knowledge of knowing past lives?
Always recollecting past events:
days, months, years, up to the womb, and even to past lives, one, ten, a hundred, a thousand, ten thousand, a million lives, up to great arhats and pratyekabuddhas knowing eighty thousand great eons;
The great bodhisattvas and Buddhas know [the past] up to immeasurable eons.
This is called the supernormal knowledge of recollecting past lives.
What is called the supernormal knowledge of knowing others' minds?
Knowing others' minds, whether defiled or undefiled, always recollecting the time when one's own mind arises, abides, and ceases, one attains [this knowledge].
Furthermore, observing others' appearances of joy, anger, fear, and terror, having seen these appearances, one then knows the mind. This is the initial approach to the knowledge of others' minds.
This concludes the brief explanation of the five supernormal knowledges.
[Sutra] The words must be trusted and accepted.
[Shastra] Gods, humans, dragons, asuras, and all great beings all trust and accept their words, because this is the retribution for not speaking falsely.
Those who speak falsely, even if they have true words, are not trusted or accepted by all people.
As a verse says:
There are those who fall into the realm of hungry ghosts, with flames coming out of their mouths,
The fourth is to speak loudly and make excessive noise, which is the retribution for verbal transgressions.
Even if one has much learning and insight, and expounds the Dharma in the great assembly,
Because of unfaithful karma, people will not believe or accept it.
If one wishes to have much learning and be believed and accepted by others,
One should be sincere and should not engage in frivolous speech!
The Sutra says: No more laziness.
The Treatise says: The dharma of laziness destroys the wealth and benefits of laypeople and destroys the heavenly bliss and nirvana bliss of renunciants.
The fame of both laypeople and renunciants is completely destroyed. There is no greater loss or greater thief than laziness.
As a verse says:
Laziness submerges good thoughts, and the darkness of delusion destroys the light of wisdom.
Wonderful aspirations are all destroyed, and great undertakings are also lost!
For this reason, it is said no more laziness.
The Sutra says: Already abandoned are material gain and fame.
The treatise states: This is the dharma of profit, like a thief, destroying the roots of merit.
It is like a heavenly hail, damaging the five grains;
The fame and profit of the world are also like this, destroying the sprouts of merit and preventing them from growing.
As the Buddha said in a parable:
It is like a rope of hair binding a person, cutting the skin and breaking the bones;
A person greedy for fame and profit destroying the roots of merit is also like this.
As a verse says:
Having entered the sandalwood forest, one only takes its leaves;
Having entered the mountain of the seven treasures, one instead takes quartz.
If a person enters the Buddha's teachings, not seeking the bliss of nirvana,
But instead seeking fame and offerings, such a person is deceiving themselves!
Therefore, the Buddha's disciples, wishing to obtain the taste of nectar,
Should abandon the mixed poison and diligently seek the bliss of nirvana!
It is like a rain of evil hail, damaging the five grains;
If one becomes attached to profitable offerings, one destroys shame, modesty, and ascetic practices.
In this world, one burns one's roots of goodness, and in the next world, one falls into hell;
Like Devadatta, who was destroyed by profit and offerings.
For this reason, it is said, One has already abandoned profit and fame.
[Sutra] Speaking the Dharma without any expectations.
[Treatise] Out of great compassion, one speaks the Dharma for the sake of the assembly, not for the sake of clothing, food, fame, or power.
Because of great compassion, because the mind is pure, and because one has attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
As a verse says:
Much learning, eloquence, skillful language, and beautiful explanations of the dharmas turn people's minds,
But if one does not practice according to the Dharma and is not upright, it is like thunder without rain.
Extensive learning, much hearing, and wisdom, but with a stammering mouth, clumsy speech, and no skillful means,
One is unable to reveal the treasure trove of the Dharma, it is like a little rain without thunder.
Without extensive learning, there is no wisdom; without being able to expound the Dharma, there is no good practice.
This bad Dharma master is without shame or conscience, like a small cloud without thunder or rain.
Much learning, extensive wisdom, beautiful speech, skillfully expounding the Dharma to turn people's minds,
Practicing the Dharma with a correct mind, fearless, like a great cloud with thunder and heavy rain.
The great general of the Dharma holds the Dharma mirror, illuminating the wisdom treasury of the Buddha's teachings,
Reciting and widely proclaiming, shaking the Dharma bell, like a ship on the ocean crossing everyone.
Also like the king of bees collecting flavors, expounding like the Buddha's words and following the Buddha's intentions,
Assisting the Buddha in illuminating the Dharma and liberating sentient beings, such a Dharma master is very difficult to encounter!
[Sutra] Transcending the profound Dharma forbearance.
[Shastra] What is the profound Dharma?
The twelve links of dependent arising are called the profound Dharma.
As the Buddha told Ananda:
The twelve links of dependent arising are profound, difficult to understand and difficult to know!
Moreover, based on the past and future, one is forever free from the net of sixty-two wrong views. This is called the profound Dharma.
As the Buddha said to the bhiká¹£us:
Ordinary beings without learning, if they wish to praise the Buddha, their praise is very little, namely praising the purity of precepts or praising the abandonment of desires.

Here, the Brahma's Net Sutra should explain in detail.
Moreover, the three gates of liberation are called the profound Dharma.
As the Buddha said in the Perfection of Wisdom Sutra, the devas praised, saying:
World-Honored One!
This Dharma is profound!
The Buddha said:
As for the profound Dharma, emptiness is its meaning, non-action and signlessness are its meaning.
Furthermore, understanding the characteristics of all dharmas as truly indestructible and unmoving is called the profound Dharma.
Furthermore, apart from the power of inner thought and cognition, one simply abides in the true characteristics of the purity of dharmas with a concentrated mind.
It is like when the yang energy is abundant, and one sees yellow when it is not yellow.
Because of the power of inner thought and cognition, one observes the transformation of dharmas, which is called shallow Dharma.
It is like when a person's eyes are pure and free from the yang energy, and they see yellow as it truly is.
In the same way, apart from the power of inner thought and cognition, the eye of wisdom is pure and sees the true characteristics of dharmas.
It is like a genuine crystal; when a yellow object is placed in it, it turns yellow accordingly, and it changes color according to whether it is blue, red, or white.
The mind is also like this. Because of the power of inner thought and cognition, ordinary beings see the different characteristics of dharmas.
Observing the true characteristics of dharmas, they are neither empty nor not empty, neither existent nor not existent.
To deeply penetrate and not regress in this Dharma, without any obstruction, is called the profound acceptance of the Dharma.
Acceptance means to attain the profound Dharma, to be replete and unobstructed, and to attain the other shore, which is called acceptance.
[Sutra] Attaining the power of fearlessness.
[Treatise] The bodhisattvas have accomplished the power of the four kinds of fearlessness.
Question:
Since the bodhisattvas have not yet accomplished what they are to do, and have not yet attained omniscience, why is it said that they have attained the four kinds of fearlessness?
Answer:
There are two kinds of fearlessness:
The fearlessness of the bodhisattvas and the fearlessness of the buddhas.

Although these bodhisattvas have not yet attained the buddhas' fearlessness, they have attained the bodhisattvas' fearlessness, and for this reason it is said that they attain the power of fearlessness.

What are the bodhisattvas' four kinds of fearlessness?
Answer:
First, because they can uphold all that they hear, attain various dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, always remember without forgetting, and have no fear when speaking the Dharma in the assembly.

Second, because they know the causes and conditions for the liberation of all sentient beings, the sharpness or dullness of their faculties, and speak the Dharma according to their abilities, bodhisattvas have no fear when speaking the Dharma in the great assembly.

Third, they do not see anyone coming from the east, south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, or the zenith or nadir to challenge them with questions that they cannot answer in accordance with the Dharma.
Because they do not see even the slightest sign like this, they have no fear when speaking the Dharma in the assembly.

Fourth, because all sentient beings listen, accept, and ask questions, and they are able to skillfully resolve all sentient beings' doubts in accordance with the Dharma, bodhisattvas have no fear when speaking the Dharma in the great assembly.

Because these deeds and affairs of the demons have all been overcome, this is called having already passed beyond the affairs of the demons.

Like the afflictions, bonds, latent tendencies, desires, fetters, and entanglements, the aggregates, realms, and sense bases, the demon king, his subjects, and his people.

Where is it said that the bonds and latent afflictions such as desire are called demons?
Answer:
In the Saá¹ƒyukta-NikÄya, the Buddha spoke a verse to the demon king:
Desire is your first army, the army of sorrow is the second,

In the five aggregates, eighteen realms, and twelve entrances, where is it said to be the demon?
Answer:
On Mount Mokuro, the Buddha taught his disciple Ruo:

As explained in the chapter on Awakening to MÄra.
Moreover, people's repeated experience of suffering and happiness in the world, due to the causes and conditions of afflictions, are also due to the power of the demon king;

Joking, laughing, speaking, singing and dancing, looking askance, and so on, arise from desire;

Sinking in the great sea of suffering, not being self-aware.

[Sutra] All karmic hindrances are completely liberated.
[Treatise] Being liberated from all evil karmic actions is called attaining liberation from karmic hindrances.
Question:
If there are three kinds of hindrances:
afflictive hindrances, karmic hindrances, and resultant hindrances;
Why abandon two hindrances and only speak of karmic hindrances?
Answer:
Among the three hindrances, the power of karma is the greatest;
Accumulating karma up to hundreds of thousands of myriads of kalpas, it is neither lost nor burned nor destroyed, and when it gives rise to its results, it does not perish.
This karma can remain for a long time and when the conditions come together, it gives rise to its results;
It is like a grain or grass seed in the ground, which grows when the time comes, without being lost or destroyed.
Even the omniscience of the buddhas, the most revered, like the king of Mount Sumeru, cannot turn these karmas, let alone ordinary people!
As a verse says:
The wheel of birth and death carries people, bound by various afflictions,
Turning with great power and autonomy, no one can stop it.
Karmas created in past lives turn into various forms,
The power of karma is the greatest, unmatched in the world!
Karmas from past lives are autonomous, causing people to experience their fruits,
Due to the power of karma, they revolve in the ocean of birth and death.
Even if the waters of the great ocean dry up and Mount Sumeru and the earth are destroyed,
Karmas created by causes and conditions in past lives are not burned or exhausted.
Karmas accumulated over a long time follow the creator wherever they go,
It is like a creditor chasing a debtor, not letting up.
These karmic fruits and retributions cannot be evaded by anyone,
There is nowhere to escape, and begging for mercy cannot avoid them.
The beings in the three realms chase after them, never leaving them for a moment,
Like the kumbhÄá¹‡á¸a demons, this is what the Buddha says about karma.
Just as the wind does not enter solid objects, and flowing water does not move upwards,
Space cannot be harmed, and karma without results is also like this.
Karmas have immeasurable power, but do not follow those who did not create them;
When the time for karmic retribution comes, they are not lost or destroyed.
Flying from the ground to the heavens, from the heavens entering the snow mountains,
From the snow mountains entering the ocean, everywhere they are not apart from.
Always and forever following me, not abandoning me for a moment;
Until reaching the time of no loss, like a shooting star heading for the moon.
For this reason, it is said that all karmic hindrances are completely liberated.
[Sutra] Skillfully expounding the Dharma of dependent origination.

Among them, the three factors of ignorance, craving, and grasping are called afflictions;
The two factors of karmic formations and becoming are called karma;
The remaining seven factors are called the fundamental events.
These twelve links of dependent origination are subsumed in the first two of the past, the last two of the future, and the eight in the middle of the present world.
This is a brief explanation of the three factors:
Afflictions, karma, and suffering.
These three factors mutually serve as causes and conditions for each other:

[Sutra] From incalculable eons ago, they have made great vows.

There is a long-lived person who, every hundred years, takes away one mustard seed until the mustard seeds are exhausted, but the eon is not exhausted.

[Sutra] The complexion is harmonious and pleasant, always greeting first, and the speech is not coarse.

[Treatise] Because the root of anger is pulled out, because jealousy is eliminated, because one always cultivates great kindness, great compassion, and great joy, and because the four kinds of wrong speech are severed, one attains a harmonious and pleasant complexion.
As a verse says:
If one sees a mendicant, one is able to treat them in four ways:

A gentle person seeking the Way, wishing to deliver all sentient beings,
Removing the four wrong verbal actions, like a horse with reins!
[Sutra] In the great assembly, one attains fearlessness.

Furthermore, because of the accomplishment of fearless dharmas, one is upright, of noble lineage, and has great power. Upholding precepts, meditation, wisdom, eloquence, and so forth are all accomplished, and therefore one is fearless.
For this reason, one is fearless in the great assembly.

Question:
It should be said that for countless billions of eons one skillfully expounds the Dharma, so why is it said to emerge?
Answer:
It is easy to expound the Dharma among those without wisdom and among disciples, but it is difficult to expound the Dharma among those with much learning, sharp wisdom, and good debate.
If a Dharma teacher has little wisdom, they will shrink back in such a place;
If they have much learning and are bold and joyful in the midst of difficult questions, they will have great authority among all the assembly.
